results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims and approach, focusing on evaluating tutor learning and the use of generative AI. "This study investigated the efficacy of various instructional conditions on tutor learning, the impact of assessment methods on learning outcomes, and the role of generative AI in evaluating tutor performance."
Sections 3.1-3.5 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including participant recruitment, lesson delivery, data collection, and analysis methods.
The document states: "The release of the data set from this study offers a valuable resource for further research on equity-focused learning and assessment."
Data is mentioned as being released, so justification for not sharing is not applicable.
While data release is mentioned, there is no explicit mention of a data dictionary or codebook explaining variables, formats, or preprocessing steps.
Data collection methods are fully described in sections 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3, detailing the use of surveys, open-ended responses, and human coding.
The document does not mention whether the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
Since code sharing is not mentioned, justification for not sharing is not applicable.
The document does not explicitly mention whether code for data preparation is shared.
Statistical tests (ANOVA, t-tests), models (Rasch model), and their application are clearly described in sections 3.4 and 4.1.
Effect sizes, p-values, and statistical significance are reported throughout section 4 (e.g., "F(1,79)= 3.20, p = .078").
Subjective context and interpretation are given when discussing the coding of open-ended responses and the rationale behind the scoring (e.g., section 3.2 and 3.3).
Data coding and analysis are clearly described, including inter-rater reliability measures (Cohen’s 𝜅) and examples of coded responses (Tables 1 and 2).
Results are clearly presented in section 4, with specific findings for each research question.
Section 5.1 discusses limitations, including sample size, scenario difficulty, and potential biases in self-reported data.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
